1999

The UN imposed sanctions against Afghanistan in an attempt to extradite Osama bin Laden

2002

North Korea was subjected to sanctions from the US as a result of its nuclear proliferation

Despite these noteworthy cases, the use of sanctions remained limited in the decades that followed, partially due to the tense geopolitical climate during the Cold War; if the US had imposed sanctions on a nation during that time, the affected country could have turned to the USSR for trade, rendering the measures worse than useless. By 1991, however, the standoff between the superpowers had cooled, and the two nations began working together on international peacekeeping.

David Cortright, Director of Policy Studies at the Kroc Institute for International Peace Studies, told World Finance: “After the end of the Cold War, there was unprecedented cooperation at the UN Security Council level, and that led to an explosion of UN peacemaking and conflict mediation efforts across the board. This was this unique historical moment with Gorbachev and the transformation of the Soviet Union, combined with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the ensuing international response, that really brought sanctions to the fore.”

Following the end of the Cold War, the sanctions imposed by the UN Security Council largely took the form of far-reaching trade embargoes – the same ‘comprehensive’ sanctions referred to previously. As the link between such sanctions and immense civilian suffering became increasingly unavoidable, however, the new millennium saw targeted measures emerge as an alternative to the all-encompassing sanctions of the past. These ‘smart’ sanctions – the likes of which are now in use against Russia – are specifically aimed at high-profile individuals or powerful groups within a targeted country in an effort to reduce the collateral damage and suffering inflicted on vulnerable civilian groups.

Limited impact 
Despite their widespread use on the international stage, economic sanctions are largely ineffective in achieving their objectives. According to leading empirical analyses, between 1915 and 2006, comprehensive sanctions were successful, at best, just 30 percent of the time. What’s more, data has shown that the longer sanctions are in place, the less likely they are to be effective, as the targeted state tends to adapt to its new economic circumstances instead of changing its behaviour.

But this is not to say sanctions are completely ineffective: in the past half-century, such measures have proved successful in peacefully resolving a number of high-stake political issues. For example, economic sanctions played a crucial role in bringing Iran to the negotiating table over its nuclear ambitions. After 30 years of disruptions to the country’s trade levels, oil production and economic performance, the UN lifted its sanctions on the nation in January 2016, having successfully convinced the Iranian leadership to comply with limits to its uranium enrichment programme.

“If we go back to the 90s, sanctions were also famously imposed on Libya because of the Lockerbie bombing”, said Cortright. “The demands were that Libya ceased its support for international terrorism and that it turn over the suspects wanted in connection with the bombings.”

While the Gadaffi regime initially refused to cooperate, years of pressure from the US and the UN eventually saw the Libyan leader hand over the suspects for trial, in addition to renouncing the nation’s weapons of mass destruction and ending its support for terrorist activities.

Despite these successes, sanctions have fallen short of achieving their objectives on numerous occasions. From Somalia and Rwanda in the early 1990s to today’s restrictions on Cuba and Russia, economic sanctions ultimately prove ineffective when there is limited international participation in the measures. Cortright explained: “In cases where the targeted country has other trading options – which is almost always the case nowadays – as the volume of world trade and investment grows, unilateral measures have no real impact.”

In our globalised world, nations are no longer required to be self-sufficient, and are able to profit from a wealth of different trade avenues. As one market closes with the imposition of sanctions, globalisation means the targeted nation can simply shift its economic focus to new markets and trading partners, bypassing sanctions and maintaining a healthy level of trade. This issue of non-participation has largely undercut the current western sanctions imposed on Russia, as the nation remains free to trade with some of Asia’s largest economies.

“Although the US and the European Union are supporting the sanctions, there are many other major economies – such as China, India and South Korea – that are not participating in the sanctions”, said Christopher Davis, a lecturer in Russian and East Asian Political Economy at Oxford University. “My calculations are that participants in the sanctions have a GDP totalling around $42trn, whereas non-participants have a total GDP of $31trn.”

Thanks to these burgeoning Asian trade partnerships, Russia has effectively created an economic bulwark against western action.

Sanctions and public opinion in Russia

Russia’s war in Ukraine continues with no end in sight.  Almost a year after the start of a full-scale conflict, one of the most intriguing questions is why the Russian people have yet to respond with a strong protest against the Putin regime’s war.  What is the basis of his power?  Why does the Russian economy still manage not to collapse in the face of unprecedented economic sanctions?  And can Russia continue to resist international pressure to deprive it of the oil and gas revenues that are fueling the war in Ukraine?Invited by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Polina Ivanova, Foreign Correspondent for the Financial Times (FT) covering Russia, Ukraine and Central Asia, covered both the Russian invasion of Ukraine  and the changes in Russia itself, from the Kremlin’s crackdown to the consequences of sanctions and attempts to circumvent them – shared his impressions of Russia, after his recent trip to Moscow.As a business journalist, she tried to explain why, despite the enormous pressure of sanctions directed against Russia in key areas – international law, finance, trade, technology, energy and against Russian elites – the Kremlin succeeded to deal with all of this.Western expectations have yet to come true, but sanctions continue to apply”The West hoped for the immediate impact of sanctions on the economy, for example, on the development of an inflationary spiral in finance, but this expectation did not materialize,” noted Polina Ivanova.  “In addition, it was expected that the sanctions would have an impact on public opinion, especially members of the elite who will find that their way of life has changed, they will not be able to go on vacation, for example, in Monaco or elsewhere… And also the middle class, who will find that certain products are no longer available. And this change in public opinion in Russia will make it more difficult for Putin to continue the war,” Polina recalled.She believes that “in the short term, these expectations were unrealistic”.Indeed, despite the sanctions, Rosstat says Russia’s GDP fell by just 2.1% over most of the last year.  At the same time, most economists are convinced that the Russian economy will face years of deterioration, contraction and regression.Polina Ivanova agrees with this.“Most of the restrictions on oil and gas came later.  Given that oil and gas make up nearly half of Russia’s budget revenue, it became clear that only now would sanctions begin to work.  It will take longer for the West to get the results it wants,” the FT correspondent noted.The role of so-called “systemic liberals” and “technocrats” was critical, according to Polina Ivanova.”Those in Russia who believed in the free market and the integration of the country into the world economy… first opposed the war, were appalled by its outbreak, and then went to great lengths to keep the economy afloat and thus enabled the continued sponsorship of this war. They made a sort of “transition”, from being horror in relation to the war, to becoming first of all, in a way, its ” assistants”, and, at the end, his “accomplices”, underlines not without regret Polina Ivanova.She gave examples of how the Central Bank of the Russian Federation, after the start of a large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine  , banned the withdrawal of money from banks for individuals, stopped the outflow capital of the country, eased the blows of the end of global payment systems in Russia, and did many other things that are likely to later, according to Polina Ivanova, her leadership “will be vindicated by the fact that they have tried to protect most people in Russia, who have long been below the poverty line.”Moscow is not the rest of Russia, but changes are beginning there”Only a small percentage of Russians, something like 7%, regularly traveled abroad for holidays, but we focus on the mood and nature of life of middle-class Russians, and especially in Moscow, because that’s what the Kremlin pays attention to. That’s where mood swings are important and can be politically sensitive,” Ivanova said.The FT correspondent tried to describe what Moscow looks like at the moment.  To do this, she suggests “putting yourself in the place of a representative of the middle class of Muscovites”:”The supermarket you went to in central Moscow looks pretty much the same as usual, western products are still there. You can buy your favorite European products, wines, your favorite western clothing brands, except that the prices have gone up a bit. You can walk down the street, look at United Colors of Benetton, look at other shops. Yes, you can’t go to Starbucks, it has changed its name and McDonald’s, but there is no there are no huge, tangible changes,” Polina said.She quoted Alexandra Prokopenko (freelance journalist and expert on Russian economic policy, in the past – adviser to the management of the Central Bank of Russia – about GA): “Billboards with portraits of the heroes of” the special operation “are hanging all over Moscow, and people are still eating fresh oysters. The war is becoming like some kind of TV show.”However, their morale changed drastically.“From the perspective of a Russian Muscovite, it is as if an atomic bomb had exploded in Ukraine, and the shock waves had not yet reached Moscow, but the radiation was already leaking.  The consequences of war are already happening in families, in people’s minds, deep inside, on a personal level, on a moral level, on a psychological level”, Polina tries to describe the mood in Moscow, “The only thing that catches people’s attention every day is empty tables, empty workspaces.If you walk into the office, you can see how many people have left.  And although estimates of how many Muscovites have left vary widely, people are constantly talking about it among themselves.  They talk about their children who left to escape mobilization, or simply acquaintances who left Russia forever.  To some extent, it’s an empty city.Parallel imports and the do-it-yourself economyPolina told how the “parallel import freedom” regime announced by the Kremlin works.“These supply chains are very unstable.  You can’t build an economy on that.  And it works especially in consumer goods. She buys the necessary goods.  They will then be transported via, for example, Kazakhstan or via Belarus to Russia.  Sometimes it works differently.  For example, a company can contact a company in Kazakhstan.  So, for example, you have a company in Kazakhstan that was ordering a certain type of computer equipment from the United States, and now it is starting to order a hundred times more than the year before.  And then, the “superfluous” goes to the company that “needs” it in Russia”, explained Polina Ivanova.The investigative reporter also explained how the oil is transported on tankers that “go with their radars turned off – the system tracking their movement – and then, somewhere in the middle of the ocean, these tankers pump oil from the ‘to another’.”The tankers built in the 80s are unusable and used to be sent to the smelter, but now they are being bought to transport oil as a sort of ‘shadow fleet’. Polina asks.” Kremlin propaganda is quite insidious: it makes people believe that there is no other reality than the one in which they exist.””Also, there is a paranoid atmosphere in Russia at the moment. IN BRIEF: Russian, US teams meet in Riyadh, hold 'serious conversation on all issues'

RIYADH, February 18. /TASS/. Following years of no communication, Russian and American delegations held a meeting in the Saudi capital Riyadh. The sides discussed rebuilding relations, preparations for a meeting between Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump, as well as prospects for resolving the conflict in Ukraine.

Russian Presidential Aide Yury Ushakov said that the teams had a "very serious conversation on all issues."

TASS has put together the highlights from the talks.

About the venue

The Russian-US talks began around 7:30 a.m. GMT in one of the palaces of the royal family: Diriyah in the Albasateen complex. The meeting lasted 4 1/2 hours.

Kremlin Spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Saudi Arabia was chosen as the venue for the talks because it suits both sides.

Members of the delegations

Russia was represented by Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov, Presidential Aide Yury Ushakov and Russian Direct Investment Fund CEO Kirill Dmitriev. US Secretary of State Marco Rubio, national security adviser Mike Waltz, and special envoy for the Middle East Steve Witkoff comprised the US team.

Subjects of the talks

The sides discussed rebuilding the entirety of Russia-US relations, preparations for a meeting between Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump, and possible negotiations on a settlement in Ukraine.

Statements by Russia

Ushakov said that the delegations had a "very serious conversation on all issues." However, it is still hard to say that the positions of Russia and the US are getting closer, according to the official. He also said Russia and the US agreed to "take into account each other's interests." According to the aide, a date for a meeting between Putin and Trump hasn’t been set and it is unlikely that it will take place next week. He said it is not yet clear who would be appointed as negotiators on Ukrainian settlement, as the president has yet to make a decision.

Dmitriev said following the talks that the Russian and US teams treated each other with respect, as equals.

"It is too early to talk about compromises. We can say that the sides started communicating with each other, started listening to each other, started the dialog," he said.

According to Dmitriev, the countries also discussed potential economic cooperation and energy prices.

Statements by the US

Rubio and Lavrov agreed to appoint respective high-level teams to begin working on a path to ending the conflict in Ukraine as soon as possible, State Department Spokesperson Tammy Bruce said in a statement. They also agreed to establish a consultation mechanism to address irritants to the bilateral relationship and lay the groundwork for future cooperation on matters of mutual geopolitical interest and economic and investment opportunities.

"One phone call followed by one meeting is not sufficient to establish enduring peace," she said separately.

Reaction from the West

Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman Maria Zakharova Moscow said the reaction of Western countries to the Russian-US talks is nervous and even hysterical. She also said there is now an "unprecedented phenomenon in international relations: efforts to impose one’s own participation in the negotiation process."

RIYADH, February 18. /TASS/. The progress in talks between Russia and the United States is possible in the next two-three months, chief executive of the Russian Direct Investment Fund Kirill Dmitriev said.

"We cannot disclose details. Everything I can say that we have a very important track on the economy. And, clearly, there is a political issue. I am not dealing with political issues but with investment and economic issues. We have a number of proposals our colleagues are thinking of. I believe progress may be achieved there not in the long run but during the next two-three months," Dmitriev noted.

Russian and US delegations are holding talks in Riyadh, where it is planned to discuss the recovery of the entire package of bilateral relations and preparations for discussions of settlement in Ukraine and the meeting between the leaders of two countries.

In recent developments, the relationship between the United States and Russia has undergone significant changes, particularly highlighted by a high-level meeting in Saudi Arabia on February 18, 2025. This meeting represented a notable shift in U.S. foreign policy under President Donald Trump, as it marked the first substantial diplomatic engagement between the two nations since the escalation of the conflict in Ukraine following Russia's full-scale invasion in February 2022. U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio led the American delegation, which included National Security Adviser Mike Waltz and Middle East envoy Steve Witkoff. The Russian side was represented by Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov, along with other senior officials, indicating a serious attempt to restore dialogue between the two countries that had been nearly severed due to the ongoing war and subsequent sanctions.<cite>https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/russian-and-u-s-officials-meet-in-saudi-arabia-without-ukraine-to-discuss-improving-ties-and-ending-war</cite>.

During the four-hour negotiations, both sides agreed to pursue three main objectives: to restore staffing at their respective embassies, to create a high-level team to facilitate peace talks regarding Ukraine, and to explore potential avenues for enhanced diplomatic and economic cooperation. Lavrov remarked that the talks were “very useful,” reflecting a mutual acknowledgment of the need to understand each other’s positions better.<cite>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cx2p7wj3yq1o</cite> This engagement stands in stark contrast to the Biden administration's strategy, which focused on isolating Russia through sanctions and international pressure, particularly in response to its actions in Ukraine and the annexation of Crimea in 2014.<cite>https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/18/world/europe/us-russia-saudi-ukraine.html</cite> 

The absence of Ukrainian officials at these talks has sparked significant concern in Kyiv, with President Volodymyr Zelenskyy stating that any decisions made without Ukraine's participation would be unacceptable. He emphasized that Ukraine views negotiations that exclude its representation as lacking legitimacy, reaffirming its sovereignty amidst growing fears of potential compromises that could disadvantage Ukraine in a peace settlement.<cite>https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/us-russia-talks-ukraine-europe-invasion-rcna192544</cite> Zelenskyy postponed a scheduled visit to Saudi Arabia, fearing it may be perceived as an endorsement of the talks being held without his country’s involvement.<cite>https://www.reuters.com/world/us-russia-agree-restore-diplomatic-missions-first-step-ukraine-war-talks-2025-02-18</cite> 

These developments have led to heightened tensions and skepticism among European allies, who worry about being sidelined in discussions critical to their security interests. French President Emmanuel Macron and other European leaders have called for an urgent meeting to address these concerns, reflecting a divide between U.S. intentions and the perspectives of European nations who view companionship with Ukraine as essential to any peace initiatives.<cite>https://www.cbsnews.com/news/us-russia-meeting-improving-relations-ukraine-war/</cite> The ongoing conversations signify a potential pivot toward a new era in U.S.-Russia relations, characterized by pragmatic approaches to longstanding conflicts and the implication of a collaborative rather than confrontational stance in international diplomacy.<cite>https://tass.com/politics/1915991</cite>

In February 2025, high-stakes talks took place in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, marking a pivotal moment in the relationship between the United States and Russia. Notably, U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov engaged in discussions aimed at normalizing diplomatic relations and addressing the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, which has been raging since Russia’s full-scale invasion in February 2022 <cite>https://www.euronews.com/2025/02/18/us-and-russian-officials-meet-for-high-stakes-peace-talks-without-ukraine<cite>. During the four-hour meeting, both sides committed to restoring staff at their respective embassies and establishing high-level teams to facilitate ongoing negotiations concerning Ukraine, an indication of a strategic shift in U.S. foreign policy under President Donald Trump <cite>https://www.rferl.org/a/us-russia-saudi-ukraine-peace-talks-riyadh-rubio-lavrov/33319124.html<cite>.

The discussions in Riyadh were framed as exploratory talks that set the stage for further negotiations, including a potential in-person summit between Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin <cite>https://www.military.com/daily-news/2025/02/18/russia-and-us-agree-work-towards-improving-ties-and-ending-ukraine-war-landmark-talks.html<cite>. Lavrov characterized the meeting as “very useful,” expressing optimism that the U.S. was beginning to understand Russia’s position <cite>https://www.rferl.org/a/us-russia-saudi-ukraine-peace-talks-riyadh-rubio-lavrov/33319124.html<cite>. However, the absence of Ukrainian representatives at these talks raised significant concerns in Kyiv and among European allies, who feared being sidelined in the negotiation process <cite>https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/russian-and-u-s-officials-meet-in-saudi-arabia-without-ukraine-to-discuss-improving-ties-and-ending-war<cite>.

As the talks unfolded, there was evident willingness from both nations to explore joint energy ventures, reflecting a mutual interest in strengthening economic ties against the backdrop of global energy challenges <cite>https://trendsnewsline.com/2025/02/19/us-and-russia-explore-joint-energy-ventures-in-saudi-talks/<cite>. This collaboration angle is significant given Saudi Arabia's role as a major oil producer and its ongoing strategic relationships with both Washington and Moscow. The U.S. and Russia’s initiative to engage on economic matters—beyond the immediate issue of Ukraine—demonstrates an overarching aim to stabilize bilateral ties and shift away from years of diplomatic isolation characterized by sanctions and hostility <cite>https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/18/world/europe/us-russia-saudi-ukraine.html<cite>.

In summary, the high-level discussions in Saudi Arabia signal a dramatic shift in U.S.-Russia relations, one that seeks to re-establish dialogues and explore mutual interests in a variety of sectors, including energy. Nonetheless, the exclusion of Ukraine from these crucial talks poses a significant threat to its sovereignty, raising alarms about the future of diplomatic negotiations and alliances in the region <cite>https://www.globalresearch.ca/global-implications-18-february-2025-us-russia-riyadh-meeting/5880542<cite>. With ongoing military actions in Ukraine and the evolving geopolitical landscape, the implications of these talks will likely resonate throughout international relations for years to come <cite>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/2/19/putin-rates-us-talks-highly-says-russia-ready-to-negotiate-over-ukraine<cite>.

The relationship between the United States and Russia has fundamentally transformed, particularly in the context of NATO and European security, due to the ongoing war in Ukraine and associated geopolitical tensions. NATO has officially designated Russia as the "most significant and direct threat" to its member states following Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. This shift stemmed from a continuous series of aggressive actions by Russia, including the illegal annexation of Crimea in 2014 and military interventions in Georgia, which raised alarms about its intentions towards NATO allies, especially those in Eastern Europe <cite>https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_50090.htm?selectedLocale=us<cite>.

In response to this threat, NATO has enhanced its collective defense measures, committing to increased military readiness and presence along its eastern flank. For example, NATO has deployed thousands of additional troops to Eastern Europe, establishing multinational battlegroups intended to deter potential Russian aggression. By 2024, approximately 40,000 NATO troops were reported to be positioned in Eastern member states, supported by significant air and naval assets, further solidifying the alliance's collective defense posture <cite>https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_50090.htm?selectedLocale=us<cite>.

The implications of this intensifying conflict extend to military spending and defense frameworks. The European allies are reevaluating their defense budgets, with many committing to increase their military expenditures in line with NATO's guideline of 2% of GDP. As of mid-2023, NATO members recognized the necessity of substantial contributions to bolster their military capabilities, drawing lessons from operational deficiencies unveiled by the ongoing conflict in Ukraine <cite>https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/in-depth-research-reports/report/nato-priorities-initial-lessons-from-the-russia-ukraine-war/<cite>. Furthermore, the war has highlighted the need for comprehensive modernization of European forces, including investments in high-intensity conflict capabilities, anti-armored defenses, and improved logistical support to ensure sustained military readiness amidst prolonged conflict scenarios <cite>https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/in-depth-research-reports/issue-brief/nato-priorities-initial-lessons-from-the-russia-ukraine-war/<cite>.

The ongoing crisis has also disrupted NATO-Russia dialogue mechanisms, particularly the NATO-Russia Council, which has not convened since the invasion, signaling a complete breakdown in cooperative security efforts that had previously characterized the relationship. This has necessitated a reevaluation of NATO's strategic concepts, as the alliance must now prepare for a future in which conventional warfare and threat proliferation by Russia become normative <cite>https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/in-depth-research-reports/issue-brief/a-nato-strategy-for-countering-russia/<cite>. As NATO seeks to reinforce its deterrent posture, the interplay of these military dynamics within the wider European context reflects a significant escalation in defensive capabilities amid a profound transformation in transatlantic security architecture <cite>https://www.gmfus.org/news/nato-and-russia-after-invasion-ukraine<cite>.

The full-scale invasion of Ukraine by Russia in February 2022 triggered a profound transformation in U.S.-Russia relations, which reached a nadir not seen since the Cold War. President Biden characterized the invasion as "naked aggression against Ukraine," leading to widespread international condemnation and a swift response in the form of severe economic sanctions against Russia <cite>https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/biden-announce-new-measures-response-russian-invasion-ukraine-rcna17523</cite>. These sanctions targeted Russian banks, elites, and crucial industries, thereby crippling Moscow's ability to acquire advanced technology essential for defense and key sectors <cite>https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/biden-announce-new-measures-response-russian-invasion-ukraine-rcna17523</cite>. Concurrently, the Biden administration assured NATO allies of its unwavering commitment to their defense, emphasizing that while no U.S. troops would enter Ukraine, decisive actions would be taken to protect NATO territories should the conflict spill over <cite>https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/biden-announce-new-measures-response-russian-invasion-ukraine-rcna17523</cite>.

Furthermore, the war prompted the U.S. to reconsider its diplomatic stance. Notably, U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio's recent meeting with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov in Saudi Arabia illustrates a shift towards diplomatic engagement, albeit without Ukrainian representation, signaling a desire to re-establish bilateral talks <cite>https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2025/02/18/russia-ukraine-war-riyadh-talks-trump-putin-rubio/5f764eb4-edc0-11ef-bd80-8f2ac5c75a8a_story.html</cite>. This meeting highlights the ongoing complexities in U.S.-Russia relations; while Biden's administration initially aimed to isolate Russia as a punitive measure for its invasion, the ramifications of the war necessitate a re-evaluation of the approach, especially considering the calls for a negotiated resolution from various stakeholders in the international community <cite>https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2025/02/18/russia-ukraine-war-riyadh-talks-trump-putin-rubio/5f764eb4-edc0-11ef-bd80-8f2ac5c75a8a_story.html</cite>. 

Additionally, the war has radicalized public opinion in both nations, with the U.S. framing the conflict as a battle between democracy and authoritarianism, thereby solidifying bipartisan support for Ukraine. The sustained Russian campaign against Ukraine, including recent drone strikes that injured civilians, reflects an aggressive strategy that deepens the U.S.'s commitment to Ukrainian sovereignty and territorial integrity <cite>https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2025/02/18/russia-ukraine-war-riyadh-talks-trump-putin-rubio/5f764eb4-edc0-11ef-bd80-8f2ac5c75a8a_story.html</cite>. In conclusion, the invasion not only altered the immediate political landscape but also reshaped the strategic underpinnings of U.S.-Russia relations, introducing a mix of punitive sanctions, diplomatic engagements, and an enduring commitment to support Ukraine in its war against Russian aggression.

The relationship between the United States and Russia has recently undergone a significant transformation, characterized by a remarkable diplomatic shift aimed at resolving the protracted conflict in Ukraine. On February 18, 2025, U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov met in Saudi Arabia to discuss a framework for peace and the potential normalization of bilateral relations. They articulated a commitment to restoring staffing at their respective embassies and forming a high-level team to facilitate ongoing discussions about ending the war in Ukraine. This meeting marked the most extensive dialogue between the two nations in over three years, signaling a departure from the isolationist policies that had defined the U.S. approach during the Biden administration, which had focused heavily on sanctions against Russia and military support for Ukraine<cite>https://www.ap.org/news-highlights/spotlights/2025/russia-and-us-agree-to-work-toward-ending-ukraine-war-in-a-remarkable-diplomatic-shift/</cite>.

Rubio emphasized that the talks were just the beginning of what would require further engagement and dialogue, outlining three central goals: diplomatic normalization, the establishment of a high-level team for peace negotiations, and the exploration of closer economic cooperation<cite>https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/18/world/europe/us-russia-saudi-ukraine.html</cite>. Lavrov echoed these sentiments, noting that both countries had begun to understand each other's positions better. This collaborative tone starkly contrasts with the previous strategy, which had centered on punitive measures against Russia following its aggressive actions in Ukraine since 2022 and the annexation of Crimea in 2014. Such aggression had driven U.S.-Russia relations to their lowest point in decades, prompting severe diplomatic and economic sanctions that isolated Moscow from the West<cite>https://www.ap.org/news-highlights/spotlights/2025/russia-and-us-agree-to-work-toward-ending-ukraine-war-in-a-remarkable-diplomatic-shift/</cite>.

The U.S. decision to engage directly with Russia regarding Ukraine has raised concerns among allies, particularly Ukraine itself, which was notably absent from the talks. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy expressed dissatisfaction at being excluded from discussions that directly impact his country's sovereignty. In a statement reflecting his frustrations, he postponed his planned visit to Saudi Arabia, indicating that Kyiv would not accept any outcomes from negotiations it did not partake in<cite>https://www.ap.org/news-highlights/spotlights/2025/russia-and-us-agree-to-work-toward-ending-ukraine-war-in-a-remarkable-diplomatic-shift/</cite>. European allies, including France, convened an emergency meeting to address these developments, emphasizing the need for inclusivity in peace talks as a core component of the international response to the conflict, which had previously relied on consultations involving European nations and Kyiv under Biden's administration<cite>https://www.ap.org/news-highlights/spotlights/2025/russia-and-us-agree-to-work-toward-ending-ukraine-war-in-a-remarkable-diplomatic-shift/</cite>.

As Russia and the U.S. embark on this renewed diplomatic engagement, the focus appears not solely on resolving the Ukrainian crisis but also on broader economic and geopolitical partnership opportunities that might emerge if the conflict is successfully addressed. Rubio described the potential for collaboration on issues of common interest as an "incredible opportunity" for both nations, underlining a shift toward a focus on diplomacy rather than confrontation. Nonetheless, this pivot is not without its complications, as military actions in Ukraine continue, with reports of Russian drone attacks highlighting the ongoing violence that complicates the path to peace<cite>https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/18/world/europe/us-russia-saudi-ukraine.html</cite>. The newly established dialogue serves as a crucial test of whether a pragmatic approach can overcome the decades-long tensions that have historically defined U.S.-Russia relations.

Spotlights
RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) — Russia and the U.S. agreed Tuesday to start working toward ending thewar in Ukraineand improving their diplomatic and economic ties, the two countries’ top diplomats said after talks that reflected an extraordinary about-face in U.S. foreign policy under President Donald Trump.
In an interview with The Associated Press after the meeting, U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio said the two sides agreed broadly to pursue three goals: to restore staffing at their respective embassies in Washington and Moscow, to create a high-level team to support Ukraine peace talks and to explore closer relations and economic cooperation.
He stressed, however, that the talks — which were attended by his Russian counterpart, Sergey Lavrov, and other senior Russian and U.S. officials — marked the beginning of a conversation, and more work needs to be done.
Lavrov echoed Rubio’s remarks and told reporters that “the conversation was very useful.”
“We not only listened, but also heard each other,” he said.
Trump’s national security adviser, Michael Waltz, and special Mideast envoy Steven Witkoff joined Rubio at the table, along with Lavrov and Russian President Vladimir Putin’s foreign affairs adviser, Yuri Ushakov.
No Ukrainian officials were present at the meeting, which came as the beleaguered country isslowly but steadily losing groundagainst more numerous Russian troops in a grinding war that began nearly three years ago.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said his country would not accept any outcome from the talks since Kyiv didn’t take part, and he postponed his own trip to the kingdom scheduled for Wednesday.
European allies have alsoexpressed concernsthat they are being sidelined.
Trump showed little patience for Ukraine’s objections to being excluded from the talks. He said repeatedly that Ukraine’s leaders never should have allowed the war to begin, suggesting the country should have been willing to make concessions to Russia before the 2022 invasion.
“Today I heard, ‘Oh, well, we weren’t invited.’ Well, you been there for three years. You should have ended it three years” ago, Trump said duringa news conference at his Florida residence. “You should have never started it. You could have made a deal.”
Ties between Russia and the U.S. have fallen to their lowest level in decades in recent years — a rift that has been widening ever since Russia illegally annexed Crimea from Ukraine in 2014 and only worsened after Moscow’s full-scale invasion.
The U.S., along with European nations, imposed araft of sanctionson Russia in an effort to damage its economy. And embassies in Washington and Moscow have been hit hard by expulsions of large numbers of diplomats, as well as other restrictions.
Rubio said Tuesday that ending the war in Ukraine could “unlock the door” for “incredible opportunities” to partner with the Russians on issues of common interest “that hopefully will be good for the world and also improve our relations in the long term.”
His comments were further evidence of the remarkable U.S. reversal on Russia after years in which Trump’s predecessor, Joe Biden, led international efforts to isolate Moscow.
Tuesday’s meeting was meant to pave the way for a summit between Trump and Putin. After the talks ended, Ushakov and Waltz said no date has been set yet for that summit. Ushakov told Russian television that a meeting was “unlikely” to take place next week, while Waltz said he thought it could be arranged in the coming weeks.
Speaking to reporters after the meeting, Lavrov mentioned the same three goals as Rubio and said that Washington and Moscow agreed to appoint representatives to carry out “regular consultations” on Ukraine.
“I have reason to believe that the American side has started to better understand our position” the Russian foreign minister said.
The meeting marked the most extensive contact between the two countries since Moscow’s Feb. 24, 2022, invasion. Lavrov and then-U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinkentalked briefly on the sidelines of a G-20meeting in India nearly two years ago, but tensions remained high.
The recent U.S. diplomatic blitz on the war has sent Ukraine and key allies scrambling to ensure a seat at the table amid concerns that Washington and Moscow could press ahead with a deal that won’t be favorable to them.
Kyiv’s absence at Tuesday’s talksrankled many Ukrainians, and France called anemergency meetingof European Union countries and the U.K. on Monday to discuss the war. Kyiv’s participation in such talks was a bedrock of U.S. policy under Biden.
U.S. State Department spokeswoman Tammy Bruce said the talks were aimed at determining how serious the Russians are about achieving peace and whether detailed negotiations can start.
Rubio said Tuesday that there would be “engagement and consultation with Ukraine, with our partners in Europe and others. But ultimately, the Russian side will be indispensable to this effort.”
Rubio also said ending the conflict would require concessions from all sides and that Washington “is not going to predetermine” what those concessions would be.
U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegsethsaid last weekthat NATO membership for Ukraine was unrealistic and suggested Kyiv should abandon hopes of winning all its territory back from Russia — twokey items on Putin’s wish list.
French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday said he spoke by phone to Trump and Zelenskyy following Monday’s European meeting.
“We seek a strong and lasting peace in Ukraine,” Macron wrote on social media platform X. “To achieve this, Russia must end its aggression, and this must be accompanied by strong and credible security guarantees for the Ukrainians,” he said and vowed to “work on this together with all Europeans, Americans and Ukrainians.”
The meeting at the Diriyah Palace in the Saudi capital of Riyadh also highlighted de facto leader Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s efforts to be a major diplomatic player, burnishing a reputation severely tarnished by the 2018killing of Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
Saudi state media described the talks as happening at the prince’s direction. Like the neighboring United Arab Emirates, the prince has maintained close relations to Russia throughout its war on Ukraine, both through the OPEC+ oil cartel and diplomatically as well.
Saudi Arabia has also helped in prisoner negotiations and hosted Zelenskyy for an Arab League summit in 2023.
But Zelenskyy postponed his own trip to Saudi Arabia scheduled for this week, suggesting that he wanted to avoid his visit being linked to the talks since Ukrainian officials weren’t invited. His visit was rescheduled for March 10.
Meanwhile, Russia continued to pummel Ukraine with drones, according to Kyiv’s military. The Ukrainian air force said Russian troops launched a barrage of 176 drones at Ukraine overnight, most of which were destroyed or disabled by jamming.
One Russian drone struck a residential building in Dolynska in the Kirovohrad region, wounding a mother and her two children and prompting an evacuation of 38 apartments, the regional administration reported.

Title: Actually, Public Health Did a Remarkably Good Job With the Pandemic - The Atlantic
Content:
Americans have been too quick to condemn the field of public health, overlooking its massive achievements in the 1900s and, yes, during the recent pandemic, too.
When caringfor two toddlers during the pandemic felt impossible, I took solace in knowing that raising children used to be considerably more difficult. During the early 20th century, infectious organisms in tainted food or fetid water exacted a frightening toll on children; in some places, up to30 percentdied before their first birthday. In those days, there was often little more to offer children suffering from dehydration and diarrhea thanmilkteeming with harmful bacteria or so-calledsoothing syrupslaced with morphine and alcohol.
Since then, deaths during childhood went from commonplace torare. Partly as a result, theaverage human life span doubled, granting us, on average, the equivalent of a whole extra life to live. The field of public health is primarily responsible for this exceptional achievement.
Medicine revolves around the care of individual patients; public health, by contrast, works to protect and improve the health of entire populations, whether small communities or large countries. This encompasses researching how to prevent injuries, developing policies to address health disparities, and, of course, tackling disease outbreaks.
George Whipple, aco-founderof the Harvard School of Public Health, proclaimed in 1914inThe Atlanticthat “one of the greatest events of the dawning twentieth century is the triumph of man over his microscopic foes.” Even he’d likely be shocked by the success of public health over the past century.
From the May 1914 issue: The broadening science of sanitation
But as the coronavirus pandemic wanes, the field of public health has come under a barrage of criticism. Some arecalling to curtail the field’s power. Even many of public health’s strongest proponents are disappointed with how the profession navigated the pandemic.
While it is essential to learn from mistakes of the recent past, such rhetoric could have awful consequences. Our public-health workforce is already burdened bymassive attrition. Simultaneously, a growing body of legislation and litigation is chipping away at public health’s ability to address current and future health threats. Politicians have accused health experts of being “wrong about almost everything” during the pandemic. Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, a Republican who fundraised his reelection bid with “#FireFauci” ads, introduced abillto eliminate the position that Anthony Fauci recently left at the National Institutes of Health and to split the agency in three.
Public health wasn’t perfect during the pandemic; itnever has been. But its remarkable track record—on the provision of clean water, prevention of childhood lead poisoning, tobacco-cessation programs, vaccine development and promotion, and much more—has driven unprecedented gains in better health and life expectancy worldwide. Public health saves lives, and is an essential component of protecting and improving our collective health.
Exacting revenge on the field following a devastating pandemic may feel satisfying to some people, but curtailing public health’s programs, credibility, and funding will not help anyone. What itwilldo is put a century of progress at risk.
Iunderstand whythe backlash has been so intense. There were errors at many steps. The CDCbotched testingfor SARS-CoV-2 early in 2020, delaying our ability to track the virus from day one. Much of the communication about masks and vaccines from public-health officials wasunclearand unhelpful. We too often failed to put our best public-health knowledge to use in schools to keep kids learning while reducing spread, leading to closures that went on far longer than necessary; at bars and restaurants down the block, meanwhile, life continued as normal. The full extent of the damage done to a generation of students will not be known for years to come.
But at the same time, while critics love to talk about everything public health got wrong throughout the pandemic, they rarely stop to recognize all that it got right—and under truly challenging circumstances. For example, when asked to reflect on the COVID-19-vaccine rollout, many will note the confusion about eligibility or countless hours spent frantically clicking “Refresh” on appointment sites. But the fact is that in just six months, almost half of the U.S. population got vaccinated. As a health-care provider, I can say that the effects were dramatic: We quickly saw fewer and fewer patients arriving with severe illness. The phenomenal achievement of the vaccination rollout—coordinated by federal, state, and local public-health agencies—averted millions of deaths from COVID-19 to date and serves as a blueprint for how to mobilize mass-vaccination campaigns in the future.
Read: 23 pandemic decisions that actually went right
Rapid antigen testing feels routine now, but consider how widespread and accessible it became, and how quickly. For the first time, people are able to easily diagnose a respiratory infection at home without a doctor, helping prevent spread and avoiding unnecessary office visits. At the outset of the pandemic, we relied on time-consuming, expensive, and severely limited PCR tests. Within months, at-home tests were approved, and now hundreds of millions have been produced, shipped, and used across the country. This helped improve timely access to antivirals such as Paxlovid, which saved more lives yet. And the lessons learned from using rapid tests in this pandemic will help bolster preparedness and response in future disease outbreaks. Additionally, at-home rapid tests for other respiratory pathogens, such asinfluenzaand respiratory syncytial virus, areon the immediate horizon.
The tendency to focus on public health’s slipups rather than its successes is not new. Americans have long undervalued public health: We almost never have to question if the food we consume or the medicines we’re prescribed will inadvertently sicken us and send us to the hospital. This disconnect between what we value and what truly benefits us becomes clearer when we compare public health with the field of medicine.
Throughout the pandemic, while public-health officials were met with pitchforks—forced out of their jobor taunted withdeath threats—health-care providers (like myself) were applauded with pots and pans, in recognition of the challenges we faced on COVID’s front lines.
This is a classically American pattern. Public health is focused on the health of communities; medicine, on individuals. Almost all of the more than $4 trillion spent on health care annually supports individual patient care, with only4 percentof funding going to public health. During these discussions, the U.S. officials indicated a willingness to consider concessions from both Russia and Ukraine, a departure from previous hardline stances. They acknowledged that discussions about territorial control and security guarantees would be essential to any peace framework. This is a crucial aspect of the negotiations, given Russia's annexation of several regions in Ukraine and its insistence on Ukraine’s neutrality regarding NATO <cite>https://www.cnn.com/2025/02/18/europe/us-russia-riyadh-talks-intl/index.html</cite>. Notably, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky expressed opposition to any outcomes from the talks without Ukraine's involvement, emphasizing that Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity must be prioritized <cite>https://www.ap.org/news-highlights/spotlights/2025/russia-and-us-agree-to-work-toward-ending-ukraine-war-in-a-remarkable-diplomatic-shift/</cite>.

Recent suggestions from U.S. Defense Secretary that NATO membership for Ukraine might not be feasible have further complicated the situation, indicating a potential shift in the American stance regarding Kyiv's aspirations <cite>https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2025-02-18/top-russian-and-us-officials-are-set-to-hold-talks-on-ukraine-war-without-kyiv</cite>.

In February 2025, a significant diplomatic shift occurred between the United States and Russia as U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov agreed to form high-level teams focused on negotiating an end to the ongoing war in Ukraine. This meeting, held in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, marked the first high-level discussion since the full-scale invasion of Ukraine by Russia in February 2022, a period during which U.S.-Russia relations had reached historic lows due to Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014 and subsequent military actions in Ukraine <cite>https://www.ap.org/news-highlights/spotlights/2025/russia-and-us-agree-to-work-toward-ending-ukraine-war-in-a-remarkable-diplomatic-shift/</cite>.

During the talks, both diplomats outlined three primary goals: restoring embassy staffing in Washington and Moscow, establishing a team dedicated to supporting peace talks regarding Ukraine, and exploring closer diplomatic and economic relations <cite>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/2/19/us-russia-talks-five-takeaways-from-rubio-lavrov-meeting-on-ukraine-war</cite>. This represents a notable reversal from previous U.S. policies under President Joe Biden, which had centered on isolating Russia through sanctions and military support for Ukraine. Analysts suggest this new approach under President Donald Trump could pave the way for future cooperation on global issues, provided a resolution to the conflict can be achieved <cite>https://www.cfr.org/article/toward-settlement-russia-ukraine-war</cite>.

However, these developing negotiations are fraught with challenges. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has firmly rejected the notion of any peace deal that excludes Kyiv, emphasizing that Ukraine must be at the forefront of any discussions regarding its future <cite>https://www.bbc.com/news/live/c4g97971rwnt</cite>. Zelenskyy expressed his concerns that U.S.-Russia discussions could undermine Ukraine's sovereignty and reiterated that his government would not accept an imposed settlement from external powers <cite>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/2/19/us-russia-talks-five-takeaways-from-rubio-lavrov-meeting-on-ukraine-war</cite>.

In parallel with these dynamics, the involvement of European allies has also become crucial. European leaders have voiced their apprehensions regarding the sidelining of Ukraine in negotiations and the broader implications for European security <cite>https://www.bbc.com/news/live/c4g97971rwnt</cite>. Countries such as France have reiterated the need for a strong and unified response to Russia's actions, reinforcing the idea that any peaceful resolution must consider the security guarantees necessary for Ukraine <cite>https://www.ap.org/news-highlights/spotlights/2025/russia-and-us-agree-to-work-toward-ending-ukraine-war-in-a-remarkable-diplomatic-shift/</cite>.

The recent U.S.-Russia meetings indicate a willingness to revisit diplomatic ties. Rubio pointed out that establishing normal diplomatic relations could unlock new opportunities for cooperation beyond the immediate conflict, aiming for an enduring solution that respects Ukraine's territorial integrity <cite>https://www.cfr.org/article/toward-settlement-russia-ukraine-war</cite>. Nevertheless, skepticism remains regarding the genuine intentions of Russia, especially in the context of its ongoing military actions within Ukraine, as evidenced by recent drone strikes that continue to ravage Ukrainian infrastructure <cite>https://www.ap.org/news-highlights/spotlights/2025/russia-and-us-agree-to-work-toward-ending-ukraine-war-in-a-remarkable-diplomatic-shift/</cite>. As these negotiations unfold, the delicate balance of interests among the U.S., Russia, Ukraine, and European nations will play a pivotal role in determining the future of peace in Ukraine.

The relationship between the United States and Russia has undergone significant transformations in recent years, particularly against the backdrop of major conflicts such as the Russia-Ukraine war. Following Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014 and its subsequent military actions in eastern Ukraine, the U.S. imposed a series of sanctions aimed at crippling the Russian economy, fundamentally altering bilateral relations. These sanctions targeted key sectors such as energy, banking, and defense, reflecting a sharp departure from previous engagement strategies and turning trust into suspicion <cite>https://www.brookings.edu/articles/why-are-us-russia-relations-so-challenging/</cite>. The ongoing conflict has not only strained these relations but has also encouraged a renewed emphasis on military alliances, particularly through NATO, which has bolstered its presence in Eastern Europe as a countermeasure to perceived Russian aggression <cite>https://russiancouncil.ru/en/analytics-and-comments/columns/military-and-security/u-s-russia-diplomatic-relations-restored-a-game-changer-for-global-stability/</cite>.

Recent shifts in U.S. foreign policy under President Trump are noteworthy, marking a potential recalibration in the path forward. In early 2025, U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov held pivotal discussions in Riyadh that announced mutual intentions to restore normal diplomatic relations after years of escalating tensions <cite>https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-us-diplomacy-breakdown-f9267ad236ecf4b4568a6d73337c6823</cite>. These talks also indicated a cooperative approach toward resolving the Ukraine conflict, suggesting that both nations may be seeking areas of mutual interest beyond their longstanding opposition <cite>https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/18/world/europe/us-russia-saudi-ukraine.html</cite>. The agreement included broad commitments to collaboration—reinstituting full embassy operations and assessing the potential for economic cooperation, which is a stark contrast to the punitive measures of previous administrations <cite>https://apnews.com/article/politics-russia-government-united-states-moscow-cbc9e5e628564a6ac36caae94a082eb6</cite>.

Moreover, this diplomatic opening comes amidst a recognition of the complex geopolitical landscape shaped by the Ukraine war. International relations have become more multipolar, with Russia looking to strengthen ties with China and other allies, thereby redefining its global standing. The impact of this realignment could have significant consequences for future U.S. foreign policy, reinforcing the need for strategic engagement rather than isolation <cite>https://moderndiplomacy.eu/2025/01/18/russia-ukraine-war-beyond-2025-shuffling-us-russia-relations-and-world-order/</cite>. As the U.S. navigates its relationship with both Russia and China, it faces the task of balancing competition with potential avenues for cooperation, particularly concerning global challenges like cybersecurity, climate change, and arms control <cite>https://www.brookings.edu/articles/why-are-us-russia-relations-so-challenging/</cite>.

The restoration of U.S.-Russia diplomatic relations could pave the way for a strategic dialogue that acknowledges the interdependence of these two nuclear powers. Both nations bear the responsibility of maintaining global stability, particularly when addressing issues such as nuclear proliferation and international security <cite>https://russiancouncil.ru/en/analytics-and-comments/columns/military-and-security/u-s-russia-diplomatic-relations-restored-a-game-changer-for-global-stability/</cite>. While the path ahead remains fraught with challenges and historical grievances, the emerging willingness to engage in talks may represent a crucial step toward mitigating conflict and fostering a more stable world order <cite>https://www.apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-us-diplomacy-breakdown-f9267ad236ecf4b4568a6d73337c6823</cite>.

The long-term effects of sanctions and isolation on Russia in the wake of its invasion of Ukraine represent a complex interplay of economic, social, and geopolitical factors. Western sanctions have severely restricted Russia's access to advanced technologies and critical imports, with the U.S. and its allies imposing over 16,500 individual sanctions targeting various sectors, including banking, energy, and technology <cite>https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-60125659<cite>. These measures have frozen approximately $350 billion of Russia's foreign currency reserves and cut off major Russian banks from the global financial system, including their exclusion from the SWIFT network <cite>https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/russia-sanctions-are-big-deal-experts-say-effects-take-years-rcna17380<cite>. Consequently, businesses face challenges maintaining operational viability; more than a thousand foreign companies have limited their activities in Russia, leading to shortages in consumer goods and technological products across various sectors <cite>https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/20/briefing/sanctions-against-russia.html<cite>.

Despite these setbacks, Russia has demonstrated a degree of economic resilience, mainly through its strategic partnerships, particularly with China and other non-Western allies. As the sanctions took effect, reports indicated that trade with China surged, with Russian oil exports to China nearly doubling to account for approximately half of Russia’s crude exports <cite>https://theconversation.com/how-russia-has-managed-to-shake-off-the-impact-of-sanctions-with-a-little-help-from-its-friends-223632<cite>. Russian officials noted that about 90% of Russian oil exports now reach Asia, benefitting from discounted prices and establishing new trade routes that bypass traditional Western channels <cite>https://www.economicsobservatory.com/sanctions-against-russia-what-have-been-the-effects-so-far<cite>. This pivot could shift the global dynamics of energy trade, allowing Russia to continue generating substantial revenue from its fossil fuel exports despite the sanctions, although it risks increasing dependency on China <cite>https://www.csis.org/analysis/strangling-bear-sanctions-russia-after-four-months<cite>.

The long-term impact of sanctions extends beyond immediate economic measures, reshaping the Russian state’s policies and societal structure. The Kremlin has increasingly militarized its economy, reallocating public funds to defense spending, which accounted for around 40% of the budget by 2024 <cite>https://cnn.com/2024/01/29/europe/russia-sanctions-putin-ukraine-economy-intl/index.html<cite>. Such prioritization has resulted in a distortion of the civilian economy, leading to reduced investments in vital public services like healthcare and education <cite>https://carnegieendowment.org/2024/03/11/why-russia-has-been-so-resilient-to-western-export-controls-pub-91894<cite>. Moreover, the continued isolation has created a public environment of propaganda and control, with state narratives establishing a sense of national resilience against Western aggression. The regime has been able to suppress dissent through strategic repression and the targeting of dissidents, consolidating power within a closed system <cite>https://www.easternherald.com/2023/01/27/sanctions-and-public-opinion-in-russia/<cite>.

In conclusion, while sanctions have succeeded in inflicting significant immediate economic pains on Russia, the long-term effects include a pivot towards alternative trade partnerships, increased militarization of the economy, and a shift in public perception shaped by state propaganda. The resilience exhibited by the Russian economy, interwoven with its adaptation and strategic sourcing from friendly nations, indicates a complex and evolving response that could sustain its governance structure and international posture despite ongoing isolation <cite>https://www.economicsobservatory.com/sanctions-against-russia-what-have-been-the-effects-so-far<cite>.

Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014 marked a significant turning point in international relations and was met with widespread condemnation from nations across the globe, particularly the United States and its allies. Following Ukraine's Maidan Revolution in February 2014, which resulted in the ousting of President Viktor Yanukovych, Russia utilized a mix of covert military operations and political maneuvering to assert control over Crimea. On March 6, 2014, the Crimean Supreme Council, backed by unmarked Russian troops, voted to join Russia, and a hastily organized referendum purportedly showed 96.7% of voters supporting this move, though the legitimacy of this referendum has been hugely disputed as it lacked credible international observation and was conducted under military occupation <cite>https://www.brookings.edu/articles/crimea-six-years-after-illegal-annexation/</cite>.

The annexation ignited a wave of sanctions from the U.S. and the European Union, targeting key sectors of the Russian economy, particularly finance and energy, asserting that these measures were necessary to uphold international law and deter further Russian aggression <cite>https://www.rferl.org/a/u-s-issues-crimea-declaration-reaffirming-rejection-of-russia-s-annexation/29390681.html</cite>. In response, Moscow has maintained that its actions were a restoration of historical justice, citing the ethnic Russian majority in Crimea and alleging that they were responding to the needs of Russian speakers facing discrimination in Ukraine <cite>https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/20/opinion/how-the-crimea-crisis-affects-us-russia-relations.html</cite>.

Despite the ongoing sanctions, Russia has sought to integrate Crimea into its federation, expending significant financial resources to develop infrastructure on the peninsula and bolster its military presence there. The Kremlin's spending has included major projects like the construction of a bridge linking Crimea to mainland Russia, which has cost approximately $3.7 billion <cite>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/5/21/the-devastating-human-economic-costs-of-crimeas-annexation</cite>. However, the aftermath of the annexation has not been without its challenges; Crimea has experienced significant economic decline due to Western sanctions, with estimates suggesting losses amounting to billions and a notable decrease in trade with Ukraine <cite>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/5/21/the-devastating-human-economic-costs-of-crimeas-annexation</cite>.

In recent years, the dynamic between the United States and Russia has continued to evolve against the backdrop of this annexation. The U.S. has reaffirmed its stance on non-recognition of Crimea's annexation even amidst fluctuating diplomatic relations, with significant attention paid to military support for Ukraine, especially during the ongoing conflict in eastern Ukraine <cite>https://www.brookings.edu/articles/crimea-six-years-after-illegal-annexation/</cite>. U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo emphasized this policy in July 2019, reiterating that sanctions would remain until Crimea was returned to Ukraine <cite>https://www.rferl.org/a/u-s-issues-crimea-declaration-reaffirming-rejection-of-russia-s-annexation/29390681.html</cite>. As tensions between the two countries have persisted, new dialogues continue to surface, yet the foundation of mistrust built upon events like the Crimean annexation remains a significant barrier in U.S.-Russia relations.

The post-Cold War developments in U.S.-Russia relations have been marked by a complex interplay of cooperation and tension, underlined by several significant events and treaties. Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union in December 1991, the U.S. and Russia entered a phase characterized by a new optimism regarding their diplomatic relationship. In early 1992, Russian President Boris Yeltsin met with U.S. President George H.W. Bush, where they issued a joint proclamation emphasizing that neither country viewed the other as a potential adversary, and they expressed a commitment to a partnership of cooperation <cite>https://www.russiamatters.org/facts/timeline-us-russia-relations-1983-2023<cite>. This period also saw the signing of the START I treaty in 1991, which aimed to reduce the two nations’ nuclear arsenals, representing a significant step toward nuclear arms control and greater security <cite>https://www.cfr.org/timeline/us-russia-nuclear-arms-control<cite>.

However, the subsequent years revealed underlying tensions, especially as NATO began its eastward expansion, which Russia perceived as a direct threat to its sphere of influence. The 1999 NATO bombing of Serbia also strained relations, as Russia opposed the intervention on humanitarian grounds and underlined its concerns over NATO's encroachment into Eastern Europe <cite>https://www.cfr.org/timeline/us-russia-nuclear-arms-control<cite>. This was compounded by the geopolitical stresses following the 9/11 attacks, where initial cooperation in fighting terrorism did not eliminate deeply rooted mistrust. The signing of the 2002 Strategic Offensive Reductions Treaty (SORT) aimed at reducing strategic warheads marked a continuation of nuclear disarmament efforts, although the lack of verification measures raised questions about its effectiveness <cite>https://www.cfr.org/timeline/us-russia-nuclear-arms-control<cite>.

In response, a more adversarial stance took shape, encapsulated by sanctions and a renewed emphasis on military alliances in Eastern Europe <cite>https://www.russiamatters.org/facts/timeline-us-russia-relations-1983-2023<cite>. The relationship seems to have entered an even more uncertain phase during the COVID-19 pandemic and subsequent global geopolitical shifts. The Biden administration's approach has focused on reasserting U.S. principles on the world stage while reaffirming commitments to NATO, prompting Russia to respond with aggressive posturing along its borders and cyber incursions <cite>https://www.russiamatters.org/facts/timeline-us-russia-relations-1983-2023<cite>. Furthermore, the recent geopolitical landscape is increasingly characterized by Russia’s alignment with China and its moves to expand influence among non-Western nations, complicating the U.S.-Russia dynamic even further <cite>https://www.cfr.org/timeline/us-russia-nuclear-arms-control<cite>. The relationship between the United States and Russia has undergone significant complexities in recent developments, particularly following high-level talks held on February 18, 2025, in Riyadh. These discussions were attended by Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov, who emphasized the necessity of improving bilateral relations to prevent deterioration and facilitate constructive dialogue. Notably, Lavrov stated, "In order to prevent the torpedoing of the establishment of relations between the Russian Federation and the United States, it is necessary to establish them," underlining a collective ambition to enhance cooperation as indicated by conversations between both nations' leaderships <cite>https://news-pravda.com/world/2025/02/18/1065815.html<cite>.

During the talks, significant focal points included addressing the protracted conflict in Ukraine and the establishment of direct diplomatic channels. Lavrov expressed gratitude to Saudi Arabian leadership for facilitating the meeting and announced plans to promptly appoint ambassadors to enhance diplomatic engagement. This move is seen as a reflection of efforts to dismantle barriers erected over the past several years, primarily under the Biden administration, which have hampered the efficacy of diplomatic missions <cite>https://news-pravda.com/world/2025/02/19/1069878.html<cite>. Additionally, a key agreement involved initiating a “process for Ukrainian settlement,” whereby the U.S. would nominate representatives for these discussions, signaling a willingness from both sides to address the conflict <cite>https://aljazeera.com/news/2025/2/19/us-russia-talks-five-takeaways-from-rubio-lavrov-meeting-on-ukraine-war<cite>.

Despite these hopeful signs, Lavrov articulated the challenges ahead, voicing strong objections to NATO's presence in Ukraine, which Russia views as a direct threat to its sovereignty. The Russian foreign minister reiterated that NATO expansion remains a pivotal issue, stating that any presence of NATO troops in Ukraine would be "completely unacceptable" <cite>https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3268643-trumps-bold-diplomacy-bridging-us-russia-tensions-over-ukraine<cite>. This position is compounded by Lavrov’s assertions regarding the implications of U.S. military support for Ukraine and the risks of escalating hostilities, which he characterized as perilous <cite>https://www.newsweek.com/sergey-lavrov-tucker-carlson-hypersonic-missiles-ukraine-1996587<cite>.

The dialogue in Riyadh marked the first high-level interaction since the onset of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022, indicating a significant thaw in diplomatic exchanges after years of strained relations. Lavrov claimed that the discussions were "highly fruitful," and he noted a mutual understanding emerging between the delegations, which he described as crucial for advancing negotiations on bilateral and geopolitical issues <cite>https://www.rt.com/russia/612953-sergey-lavrov-russia-us/<cite>. In this evolving landscape, both nations recognized the necessity to engage constructively to manage their diverging interests without inciting further confrontations <cite>https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2025/02/19/3260781/russia-us-agree-to-resolve-diplomatic-mission-issues-says-lavrov<cite>. 

The potential for a summit between Presidents Putin and Trump has also been highlighted as a key outcome of these diplomatic efforts, suggesting that both countries are taking steps to lay the groundwork for higher-level discussions that could influence future relations. As Lavrov noted, establishing operational norms for diplomatic missions will be paramount for achieving any sustainable agreements moving forward, and he reiterated that the U.S. and Russia should work together on issues of mutual concern while striving to resolve conflicts amicably <cite>https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3272491-geopolitical-tensions-and-divergence-the-g20-meeting-in-south-africa-amidst-ukraine-conflict<cite>.
